list.item: Encoding has been done using the recommendations for Level 3 of the "TEI in Libraries Guidelines."
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Print page headers and side descriptions are not included.
OCR successfully reproduced simple tables, but complex tabular data is not captured dependably and the results should not be relied upon.
OCR was not able to successfully reproduce math and chemical formulas. The uncorrected results remain in the text.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, smallcaps, strikethrough, subscript, superscript, underline. The following print styles are ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is indicated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for future entry subsections.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze using machine-learning methods.

Subject keywords are added to teiHeader for each entry; they were generated by the HIVE2 automated vocabulary server, created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: This release reproduces the text matter for all entries. It does not include images, front- or back-matter. The reproduction of tables and formulae is unreliable.

prefixDef.p: URIs with the prefix fastgeo: point to terms in the OCLC FAST (Faceted Application of Subject Terminology) Geographical subject heading schema derived from the Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH).

URIs with the prefix fasttopic: point to terms in the OCLC FAST (Faceted Application of Subject Terminology) Topical subject heading schema derived from the Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH).
URIs with the prefix lcsh1910: point to subject terms in Subject Headings Used in the Dictionary Catalogues of the Library of Congress, 2 vols., Library of Congress, 1910.
URIs with the prefix ht: point to page images in the Hathi Trust.
URIs with the prefix ia: point to page images in the Internet Archive.
URIs with the prefix nls: point to page images in the National Library of Scotland.

div.p: DONATUS, Aelius, a grammarian and rhetorician, who taught at Rome in the middle of the 4th century a,d., had the honour of numbering St Jerome among his pupils, and was the author of a number of professional works. We still possess his Ars grammatica, consisting of three parts, De Uteris,syllabis, pedibus et tonis, De octo partibus orationis, and De barbarismo, solecismo, schematibus, et tropis; tho larger portion of his commentary on Terence, in a greatly interpolated condition; and a few fragments of his notes on Virgil preserved and severely criticised by Servius. The first of these works, and especially the section De octo partibus, though possessing little claim to originality, and in fact evidently based on the same authorities which were used by Charisius and Diomedes, attained such popularity as a school-book that in the Middle Ages the writer’s name became a common metonymy for a rudimentary treatise of any sort, and bade fair to furnish as permanent an addition to the English vocabulary as has been obtained in French from the name of Calepinus. Avaricia, for example, in the Vision of Piers Plowman, tells how he “drowe among draperes his donet to learn;” and bishop Pecock published about 1440 a Donat into Christian Religion. On the introduction of printing the little book was one of the first rendered accessible by the new process, and editions were soon multiplied to such an extent that the bibliography of Donatus is nearly as intricate a subject as that of the Bible. Copies still exist, though in a mutilated condition, of impressions produced by the early wooden-block system, details about which may be found in Sotzmann’s “Aelteste Geschichte der Xylographie” in the Historische Taschenbuch for 1837. The Ars Grammatica is reprinted by Putsch in Gram. LatinaeAuctores Antiqui, Hanover, 1605, and by Lindemann in CorpusGrammaticorumLatinorum, vol. í; and the Commentaries on Terence, first published at Rome in 1472, may be found in Klotz’s edition of the dramatist, 1838-40. The Commentary on Virgil discovered by J. Jovian Pontanus, and published by Scipio Capecius at Naples in 1535, is the work of a later grammarian of the same name, Tiberius Claudius Donatus.
See Teuffel, History of Roman Literature, vol. ii., and the writers there referred to.
